First, using these differentmodalities of data, one can calculate various input measures as independent variables. Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: Second, education with fully automated systems that externalise human cognition to de-liver educational practice can be argued to dehumanise learning. When AI in education isconsidered in a narrow sense, as lonely individual learners working on their own with an AIsystem, this might indeed lead learners to prioritise information gathering and declarativeknowledge acquisition over tacit knowledge and wisdom which comes through rich expe-riences in the real world. Particularly, if these systems are considered as a replacementfor human interactions with each other, and with the real world, then the knowledge thatcomes through experience and practical acquisition of an embodied skill can be replacedwith tokens of representations that are far off the actual construct. Learning is not onlyabout absorbing information and education is not only about learning. These are also aboutdeveloping social competence, emotional intelligence and various metacognitive abilities inreal-world interactions as well as serving other societal needs.
Comment text: I quite emphatically agree with the sentiment that "Learning is not only about absorbing information and education is not only about learning," involving also secondary layers that relate to different types of/multiple intelligences! This is something that is not often seen or cared about (to the extent that it should be) especially in catering to students with multiple different learning styles, engaging in different ways (different user types, as in my project educational practice/case study with gOPAL ﻿#project﻿). It definitely does influence intrinsic motivation and one's ability to sustainably keep studying the material and construct a positive path forward!

Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: What do I mean by AI as tools?
Comment text: ﻿@Tiarra Baker﻿ said:The idea of AI as a tool is intriguing to me because I think that there are many people especially students in the K-12 setting who misuse AI and fully rely on it instead of using it as a tool. I believe that it's because students are not trained in using AI, thus the only way they know how to use AI is to receive answers from it. I wonder how we can help students understand AI as a tool?Thank you﻿@Tiarra Baker﻿  for sharing this insightful reflection. I completely agree—positioning AI as a tool rather than a crutch is essential, especially in K-12 settings where students are still developing foundational skills in critical thinking and digital literacy. The misuse or overreliance on AI often stems not from malintent, but from a lack of structured guidance on how to engage with AI thoughtfully and responsibly.To help students understand AI as a tool, I believe we need to embed AI literacy directly into the curriculum. This could include age-appropriate lessons on what AI is, how it works (in simplified terms), and what its limitations are. Practical activities that encourage students to interact with AI—such as prompting AI to brainstorm ideas, compare versions of text, or critique an AI-generated output—can help shift the mindset from passive consumption to active collaboration.

Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: Third, a significant amount of work is still needed to address socio-psychological barriersto the use of AI in educational contexts. Students need to be motivated enough to engagewith AI tools in the first place, yet only about 5% of them manage to engage with educationalresources long enough on their own to get statistically significant benefits (Weatherholtzet al., 2022). In addition, teachers and learners tend to have confirmation biases and un-realistic expectations from AI (Nazaretsky et al., 2021). Previous research showed thatwhen people are presented with content framed as coming from AI, they tend to judge itas less credible and trustworthy compared to the same content framed as products of edu-cational psychology or neuroscience (Cukurova, Luckin, & Kent, 2020). Similar results arenow emerging, when AI- generated content or feedback is presented to teachers and stu-dents they tend to judge its quality lower and trust it less if they know that it is AI generated(Nazaretsky et al., 2024). There is emerging work focusing on how we measure and gain thetrust of teachers and learners in AI, but considerably more research is needed in this spaceto optimise their trust (eg, Nazaretsky et al., 2022).
Comment text: This part addresses a crucial but often underexplored dimension of AI integration in education: the socio-psychological barriers that hinder its effective use. It draws attention to the persistent challenge of student motivation, noting that only a small fraction—approximately 5%—engage with AI-enabled educational resources long enough to derive meaningful learning outcomes (Weatherholtz et al., 2022). This statistic underscores the need for designing AI tools that not only deliver content but also sustain learner engagement through personalized, interactive, and emotionally attuned experiences.
Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: In this regard, another conceptualisation of AI can provide significant opportunities. AI canalso be conceptualised as computational models of complex learning phenomena for hu-mans to internalise and change their representation of thought (Kent et al., 2021). Theselead to relatively low automation systems that allow high human agency and control (see theAIED- HCD conceptual framework in Figure 2).In learning sciences literature, it is well established that learning may be facilitated withmental models (Johnson- Laird, 1983). Mental models help us explain and predict how peo-ple interact with the world, and how they explain, understand, solve anticipated events andcommunicate. While mental models are internal structures, they can be exteriorised whentriggered by interaction (Bransford et al., 2000). The assumption in this conceptualisation ofAI is that computational models can offer an externalisation trigger for mental models. Bythat, they can serve as a learning affordance, and the learning outcomes can be observedthrough changes in learners' language, and their ability to explain, predict or diagnose phe-nomena (Kent et al., 2021). So, although everyone comes to a learning situation with theirown mental model of what success looks like, as well as the models that learners hold aboutthemselves (Byrne, 1992), we can use data to model what success looks like with computa-tional approaches and present these models back to people and trigger them to refine theirmental models.This conceptualisation allows more opportunities for researchers interested in under-standing and designing learning environments through the lens of constructivist and socio-cultural learning perspectives. It allows opportunities to focus on AI models to help developlearner competence through rich learning experiences and reflecting on these experienceswith the help of computational models
Comment text: It reimagines AI not as a tool of automation but as a cognitive partner that models complex learning phenomena to support the development and refinement of learners’ mental models. It encourages the design of low-automation, high-agency systems that foster metacognition and learner autonomy. This perspective invites rich pedagogical and ethical questions: How can AI be designed to prompt meaningful self-explanation and conceptual change? What kinds of data or language patterns best indicate a transformation in thinking? How can we ensure that such systems are accessible and culturally responsive, reflecting diverse ways of knowing rather than imposing narrow models of success? Finally, what role should teachers play in mediating student interactions with AI and interpreting computational representations of learning?

They also lack clear, reliable and valid measuresof success in educational contexts which makes it difficult for performance evaluations inreal-world implementations

Comment text: This is true ﻿@Dana McCool﻿ , thank you for the reminder. Indeed, most Opensource AI are basically collecting and mixing all possible data available on every possible topic. And we all know that what is said on the internet is not always true...whether published by AI or by humans ! Fake news or misinformation is a problem we have to be aware about when using AI. Let's not forget that the AI has no brain or autonomy: it simply reproduce what is the most likely to be a convenient or correct answer according to all the available data treated in its system. If the vast majority of people says that the sky is pink tomorrow, AI will probably tell you that the sky is pink...even if it is not. And it could even invent fake (but credible) sources to convince you ! Some very interesting research begin to emerge about that problem.

Highlighted text: . Humans are very good at many things that today's AI is still pretty poor at, andAI is good at some others.
Comment text: I personally would like to agree with that sentence...and I was, actually, agreeing with it until recently. However, it seems that AI is becoming stronger and more powerful everyday, to the point where most of people are getting scared of being replaced by AI in their jobs. I don't want to sound pessimistic, and I really hope I am wrong on this one - but regarding the both fascinating and scary progress AI is making everyday in so many different fields, I now doubt that we can say that AI is still poor at many things. 2 years ago with the emergence of Midjourney or Stable Diffusion/ Dall-E, people where still clearly able to recognize and criticize an AI-generated picture. It becomes more and more complicated because they increased to the point to reproduce almost everything perfectly, humans included. AI is now able to generate images, photographs, graphic design, illustration, poetry, essays, songs, etc as well as most artists. It is able to give you advice about law and legal procedure to the point to lawyers or legal advisers are feeling threatened. It is able to simulate a social interaction with a friend or a confident, reproduce human emotion or dialogue when you are in trouble, and simulate compassion and attention to the point where people are preferring virtual AI partners over real ones, or are using AI as a therapist. All of those infinite possibilities reproducing human work as well (sometimes maybe better) as humans, but for free. Can we really still believe that AI is too poor at most of the things we ask it to do to really have a serious impact on human's work ? I'm genuinely asking the question.

Highlighted text: . For instance, we have beenworking on models that detect speech in groups, transcribe it from speech to text and labelthe text with groups' challenge moments in their collaborative discourse (Suraworachetet al., 2024). Then, these detected challenge moments are also sent back to students asfeedback with visualisations and further explanations based on the threshold values oncertain aspects and diagnosed challenges, building upon the human interpretation of thesevalues and providing suggestions on how to address these challenges in their next groupactivities. Rather than assuming what is being modelled and detected as the reality, we alsoprovide students with their own transcriptions, as well as the details on how these modelsare built, and their episode-level and sentence-level predictions. So, they see the sense-making process we use in detail and interpret it themselves when such feedback is valuable,or when it is safe to be ignored.
Comment text: This is an interesting use of AI to encourage group work in classrooms. I assume it could be an interesting tool for the students (as mentionned in the article) but also for the teacher, since most of the time it is hard for the teacher to keep track of what is exactly going on with each group during group activities in class. In my experience, the teacher circulated between groups and try to help them one by one, and it can lead to encouraging the other groups that are not being observed by the teacher to be distracted or to talk about other things (or switch to their native language in language classes, for example). I guess that those kind of "tracking" AI tools could encourage (force ?) students to stay on track and actively participate in group work rather than relying on others. However, I must say I hope it will not turn into a kind of "Big Brother" tool that will make the students feel constantly watched, judged and graded by a machine, removing all the authenticity of exchanges.

Comment text: ﻿@Macha Petre﻿ said:This is an interesting distinction to do. I guess it also reflects the current debate our society is having about the use of AI - To what extent should we use it, or be allowed to use it ? Should we let it replace humans' job ? Should we restrain ourselves to use a tool that allow us infinite possibility and is able to multiply productivity by 1000 ? I feel like the general "mainstream" view about this reflects the one most teachers have towards AI in classroom: it should be used sporadically, by making it easier for you to do your work, rather than doing your work for you. The problem is that the line is often hard to draw between what is honest facilitation/help allowed by technology (such as looking for the translation or the definition of a word in Google rather than using an old, big dictionnary) and what is academic dishonesty/cheating (just writing an entire essay in english and then copy and paste it through ChatGPT or Google Translate to translate it in the target language)﻿@Macha Petre﻿ You raise an important point: the very dilemma you describe—where technology can both empower and undermine learning—reflects a broader societal negotiation about AI’s role. In the classroom, then, our task is not simply to ban or embrace AI wholesale, but to articulate clear pedagogical boundaries: we permit tools that scaffold students’ work (e.g. quick look‑ups or grammar checks) while requiring authentic engagement for tasks that assess critical thinking or original expression. By embedding AI literacy into our curriculum—teaching when and how to deploy these tools responsibly—we help students navigate that fine line between legitimate support and academic dishonesty, ensuring that productivity gains amplify rather than replace genuine learning.

Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: . Humans are very good at many things that today's AI is still pretty poor at, andAI is good at some others.
Comment text: ﻿@Macha Petre﻿  You raise an important and increasingly shared concern. As AI systems grow more sophisticated—capable of producing images, texts, and interactions that rival human outputs—it becomes harder to claim they are simply poor substitutes. However, while AI can now mimic the products of human labor with impressive accuracy, it still lacks the processes that give those products depth: intentionality, lived experience, ethical reasoning, and contextual understanding. Rather than dismissing AI’s progress, we might shift the conversation toward what uniquely human capacities we value and how education can cultivate them alongside, not in competition with, intelligent systems
Document: [annotation required] The interplay of learning, analytics and artificial intelligence in education: A vision for hybrid intelligence

Highlighted text: nificant amount of work is still needed to address socio-psychological barriersto the use of AI in educational contexts. Students need to be motivated enough to engagewith AI tools in the first place, yet only about 5% of them manage to engage with educationalresources long enough on their own to get statistically significant benefits
Comment text: This passage importantly highlights that the success of AI in education is not just a technical issue, but a deeply human one. Motivation, trust, and sustained engagement are crucial for learners to benefit meaningfully from AI tools. The fact that only about 5% of students persist long enough to see real gains suggests a need to design AI tools that are not only intelligent but also emotionally and socially responsive. Without addressing these socio-psychological barriers, even the most advanced AI will fall short in real-world educational settings. We need to convince students that the technology is useful and meaningful for them.

So, the impact of AI in education is not only dependent upon the AItool itself but the particular learning design and the instructional design in which they areembedded.

Once we are able to set up these norms, students will be more likely to use it correctly. While this will never be 100% true for all users. It can be beneficial for most.

Comment text: "Stochastic parrot" really gets to the heart of how LLMs work and their limitations. They do not understand in the way that humans do but can imitate the ways that humans speak and given answers. The LLMs generate what is the most likely answer to the user's question given the data set available to the LLM.

Comment text: I think an AI education that emphasizes human agency and human-centered design could help build trust in AI tools broadly. Outside of the education field, proponents of AI often push AI tools as a way to eliminate certain jobs and tasks normally done by humans which I think contributes to distrust in AI among some people. In addition, giving people skills for using AI instead of telling them how to use AI enables the type of autonomy that is essential to engaging with a tool beyond a surface level use.

Highlighted text: 2022). In addition, teachers and learners tend to have confirmation biases and un-realistic expectations from AI (Nazaretsky et al., 2021). Previous research showed thatwhen people are presented with content framed as coming from AI, they tend to judge itas less credible and trustworthy compared to the same content framed as products of edu-cational psychology or neuroscience (Cukurova, Luckin, & Kent, 2020). Similar results arenow emerging, when AI- generated content or feedback is presented to teachers and stu-dents they tend to judge its quality lower and trust it less if they know that it is AI generated(Nazaretsky et al., 2024). There is emerging work focusing on how we measure and gain thetrust of teachers and learners in AI, but considerably more research is needed in this spaceto optimise their trust (eg, Nazaretsky et al., 2022)
Comment text: This series of studies is interesting given the amount of attention AI has received in previous years. I wonder what specific factors have built this distrust? Also, could building trust in AI among educators require an effort that is educator led?

Comment text: I think this is a really important section to highlight.  Yes, AI can do a lot for us, but it can't replace the knowledge that is learned through complex socio-cultural experiences. It can't tell us how to feel or impart genuine and meaningful experiences, understand how different cultures or people construct meaning in their lives.  As I referenced in a previous post, I also don't think it can solve problems based on a host of ethical considerations and a deep knowledge of your profession, culture and people involved.  I like that this article places it as a partnership tool and I think for many who think they can replace people with AI in some areas, they will regret the outcomes. Perhaps it can be seen as a partner that reduces some our work so that we have more time for the really complex tasks.

Highlighted text: In this regard, another conceptualisation of AI can provide significant opportunities. AI canalso be conceptualised as computational models of complex learning phenomena for hu-mans to internalise and change their representation of thought (Kent etal.,2021). Theselead to relatively low automation systems that allow high human agency and control (see theAIED- HCD conceptual framework in Figure2).In learning sciences literature, it is well established that learning may be facilitated withmental models (Johnson- Laird,1983). Mental models help us explain and predict how peo-ple interact with the world, and how they explain, understand, solve anticipated events andcommunicate. While mental models are internal structures, they can be exteriorised whentriggered by interaction (Bransford etal.,2000). The assumption in this conceptualisation ofAI is that computational models can offer an externalisation trigger for mental models. Bythat, they can serve as a learning affordance, and the learning outcomes can be observedthrough changes in learners' language, and their ability to explain, predict or diagnose phe-nomena (Kent etal.,2021). So, although everyone comes to a learning situation with theirown mental model of what success looks like, as well as the models that learners hold aboutthemselves (Byrne,1992), we can use data to model what success looks like with computa-tional approaches and present these models back to people and trigger them to refine theirmental models.This conceptualisation allows more opportunities for researchers interested in under-standing and designing learning environments through the lens of constructivist and socio-cultural learning perspectives. It allows opportunities to focus on AI models to help developlearner competence through rich learning experiences and reflecting on these experienceswith the help of computational models
Comment text: ﻿@Nansong ZHOU﻿ I appreciate your focus on being accessible, culturally responsive and reflecting diverse ways of knowing.  As I understand it, AI is pulling in everything that is "out there" and everything that has already been inputted by other people.  But if the inputs are biased or represent majority culture or certain ways of knowing have been overly used as the source material, this will skew what comes out and is not representative of the larger diversity of thought.

Highlighted text: . For instance, we have beenworking on models that detect speech in groups, transcribe it from speech to text and labelthe text with groups' challenge moments in their collaborative discourse (Suraworachetetal.,2024). Then, these detected challenge moments are also sent back to students asfeedback with visualisations and further explanations based on the threshold values oncertain aspects and diagnosed challenges, building upon the human interpretation of thesevalues and providing suggestions on how to address these challenges in their next groupactivities. Rather than assuming what is being modelled and detected as the reality, we alsoprovide students with their own transcriptions, as well as the details on how these modelsare built, and their episode-level and sentence-level predictions. So, they see the sense-making process we use in detail and interpret it themselves when such feedback is valuable,or when it is safe to be ignored.
Comment text: ﻿@Macha Petre﻿ Excellent points, and I think this ties in with later in this reading where it mentions (another good point) that we have to be careful to strike a delicate balance between teacher/student ease of use and accessibility and the potential it gives to advance AI in education. This is why I'm hopeful about the increasingly prominent role AI plays, since its technology its evolving to the point where it can do a lot of the work behind the scenes and not end up having to turn into a Big Brother tool! It can run silently in the background as assistance *whenever necessary* to simplify complicated or inaccessible teacher tasks and not ruin the learning experience.
